H0.text: Which pernicious elements of war were said to be uncontrollable and inhumane by the UN. Landmines

H1.text: Which pernicious elements of war were said to be uncontrollable and inhumane by the UN. Cluster Bombs

H2.text: Which pernicious elements of war were said to be uncontrollable and inhumane by the UN. Chemical Warfare

H3.text: Which pernicious elements of war were said to be uncontrollable and inhumane by the UN. Fougade

A4.text: The use of land mines is controversial because of their indiscriminate nature and their potential to remain dangerous many years after a conflict has ended, harming civilians and the economy.

A5.text: The use, transfer, production, and stockpiling of cluster munitions is prohibited by the international CCM treaty. If bomblets do not explode, they are referred to as unexploded ordnance (UXO), along with unexploded artillery shells and other explosive devices that were not manually placed (that is, mines and booby traps are not UXOs).

A6.text: Cluster munitions left behind after conflicts can remain dangerous for decades, as evidenced by the continued casualties in Laos from unexploded ordnance as of 2009.

A7.text: The use, transfer, production, and stockpiling of cluster munitions is prohibited by the international CCM treaty, which was supported by a number of UN agencies and approximately 30 governments.
